column228: Most of these suggestions/criticisms are things that I have seen from the track testing server, council, and admin functionality. I'm going to be as upfront as possible because I could see some genuine changes being enforced to help in certain areas: - Admins should have better communication and transparency between each other. I'm not sure what happens in admin chat, but it is clear that there exist times where admins are not always on the same page. One of the more recent examples is with ghost-setting: Echo saying to do one thing while bento and Cotni say something else (ex: what the difficulty should be for certain tracks like Delfino Island; heck we don't even know what ghosts we're using). I think part of this issue is that Echo isn't the most active admin out there (don't get me wrong, I have a lot of respect for him, but sometimes I do question his presence as an admin versus playing in t3/t4 lounge). I totally understand that admins might be overwhelmed and busy, which is why I think there needs to be a fourth admin (I think admins mentioned a while back about adding a CT creator as an admin down the road?). If not, I would highly suggest having people help you guys out with simple tasks, such as updating the Backrooms sheet to reflect the most recent szs files and the most recent ghost times. Something like not acknowledging Flint's GBA LC update on the sheet for 4 months should not have flown by admins, and there should probably be some sort of system to track these updates. I am someone that believes in having things done in a timely fashion to reflect the situation of CT updates, and I think there needs to be more communication among ALL admins to ensure that this is done. This collectively transitions into the next point: - Being more direct / having improved guidelines. This may seem like a broad point, but I have also gotten the impression that admins are not as consistent and "strict" as they need to be in enforcing certain aspects. One specific example is ghost-setting. Last update, bento decided to give ghost-setters what ended up being a month extra to complete their ghosts, which made the distance between updates almost 5 months. We were under the impression that the update would include Bean's security fixes, but ultimately it was not added, and thus the long extension came from people not doing ghosts on time. It baffles me that people could not spend 15 minutes to complete an easy staff ghost, and that this was the primary cause of the update being extended outward. I would recommend admins encouraging people to set backup times early in the process, possibly assigning certain people to do backup ghosts. If the community found out that the longer-than-anticipated wait was because of a few people not doing ghosts, I'm sure they would be (reasonably) upset. The other major example I can think of is enforcing council strikes. I remember a couple weeks back when bento posted the theoretical number of strikes everyone would have, should they be enforced properly. It shocked me that some people would have received double-digit strikes. I understand missing a few assignments, but council is about committing to helping to improve tracks, and if people aren't willing to do that, then they should be striked, warned, and sternly talked to by admins. It's unfortunate that we barely got 2/3rds of council to vote on FR's GBA PC, as these reviews are ultimately to help the creator's track succeed. Deadlines should be deadlines; people shouldn't be let off the hook for submitting almost an entire day late when they had 3 weeks to complete a track review (albeit the track was short and simple). I'm glad we are getting to reflect on what we analyze for track reviews, and these sorts of discussions should be done more. tl;dr: admins should have clearer organization and standards when dealing with council strikes, ghost-setting, getting forms out in time (heck I had to ping admins to get this form out and bento "assumed" it was already done). - Improve variance in expert staff ghosts. As someone that has tested each and every update track on TTs, I do question some of the times admins create. A lot of the times seem "mid difficulty" since they seem to be around the average of ghostbusters submission times, but I think these should be used moreso as a reference for "should we make this track harder or easier than the average time? and by how much?". Even with this "hard update", there were no crazy difficult time ranges (as someone that beat all 10 update tracks' timeranges and/or ghost times); this kinda connects to the first point of Echo wanting ghosts to be "difficult" whereas bento and Cotni were not on the same page. After we had discussed keeping DKJ reasonable, oj wanted to make a much more difficult time without the permission of all three admins (only Echo agreed at first). My point is this: if admins create a more diversified range of ghosts for each update (ex: 1 easy, 3 easy/medium, 3 medium/hard, 2 difficult, 1 brutally difficult), then there would be less controversy about ghost setting times, especially since the difficulty of ghosts would cater to everyone (both casual and more experienced TTers). I feel like 80% of the recent ghosts have all been within the realm of "medium" difficulty; if you ask me I think every update should include at least one or two DS Mario Circuit difficulty ghosts (or easier) and at least one or two DBG/magmatic difficulty ghosts (or harder). I feel like you'd see less complaining if there was at least one or two ghosts that could be "accessible" to everyone. - I mentioned this in the second point, but actually enforcing council strikes on time; people aren't going to take the strike system seriously if they aren't enforced. - Introduce council polls. I think certain discussions we have in council (ex: do we review track X as a shadow submission since it was highly mentioned in this form) deserve to be voted on by council more often. One system that we could consider implementing is having a "ticket" system for submitting poll ideas (anonymously so that other council members don't know, similar to Lounge), and if admins approve of the suggestion, then we poll it. This doesn't have to be for just track reviewing, but even something like the recent question regarding the certain point in the Aqua Dungeon summary being addressed. - Have Council "events", such as Council wars. I think this could be a cool way to have people in Council interact and get to know others more while having some fun.  I have immense respect for admins, Bean, and our CTGP community, but I definitely think that work needs to be done.

column228: A lot of CT creators are unaware of the unspoken expectations coming from the comp side of council. Comp very much has its own metagame that rarely aligns with the ambitious designs authors opt for, leading to unforseen and inconsistent decisions.  So, I recommend two changes:  1. Figure out what these comp expectations are, and articulate that on the track wishlist, so creators know what they are getting into upfront. 2. Add a new way for tracks to be accepted, in addition to the regular vote. For example, tracks could also be accepted if a large majority of either casual or comp players vote for it (>90% maybe).  Comp preferences are very often presented as objective fixes in track summaries, and it isn't fair to pressure authors into pandering to what is essentially a vocal minority. They should be able to make the tracks they want, taking the chances they want, and still have a way to get realistically accepted.  If creators want to appeal to comp that is okay too obviously, but it should never feel like a requirement. The system needs to be transparent, and friction between casuals and comps needs to be minimized. Thank you.

column227: I'm still waiting for track author credits in game. The Skill Issue Pack includes this feature, and it is a useful part in appreciating creators' work and simultaneously understanding the track list. As a creator, I want myself and others to receive the recognition they deserve for making these tracks. Please implement this feature soon.  CTGP's track selection menu needs a rework. Another change to improve track visibility is to implement track preview images. To some extent, every Mario Kart game provides a track preview when selecting it. It helps people visually recognize the track and associate that preview with its name. However, it's the standard in MKW modpacks to have a blank background when highlighting tracks. I find this confusing. Often tracks have similar names that make it confusing to find the one you're looking for. For example, if you're wanting to choose Citrus' CT jungle track with waterfalls and can't remember the name, how can you find it from Jungle Cliff, Jungle Glade, Jungle Jamble, & Jungle Ruins? It just isn't intuitive to guess by name and eventually figure out that Jungle Glade is the one you're looking for. A noclip screenshot for every track would help immensely in navigating 250 tracks. The only roadblock (beside the technical end) is that each track update would require more effort to produce, but I am confident that this will ease players into the track list better and make it accessible to someone who plays infrequently.

column231: As a CT creator with declining interest in MKW, take my opinion for what you will.  I feel that CTGP is treading water. Bean's current actions are maintaining current code and ghost database infrastructure, developing 24-player mode (which appears to have stalled and will offer no impact on people who aren't streamers), and adding track updates every couple of months. These result in a stable distribution with an occasional track update every so often. This relatively unchanging state is what I imagine makes CTGP appealing for a lot of the community, but to me, it highlights what I dislike in the pack.  I am ultimately not interested in many tracks in the pack. Multiple popular online tracks are ones I have no interest in. Mushroom Peaks is the easy one to point out since it is the most popular, but a couple other consistent top 20 tracks are ones I have no interest in playing. Retro tracks take up a sizable portion of the track list, and they offer little appeal to me in this game. I find they often are more compelling in their original games. I would rather have more room for new CT experiences that I cannot get elsewhere. Even with plenty of solid new tracks, they barely alter what is and has been the CTGP experience that I've grown increasingly negative to.  How I view it is that CTGP sets the technical standards for what creators can design, and it is disappointing having no new features for the pack. Any creator that wants their content to have potentially high play counts needs to be in CTGP and meet its standards of base MKW tracks with the occasional consideration of 200cc. As a creator, I think this is limiting what the community produces. None of the ambitious ideas possible with LE-code (or its alternatives), sound triggers, or a fully fledged battle mode are really explored because CTGP doesn't support it. I believe that CTGP needs more technical possibilities to showcase new ideas and facilitate the creation of new ones. Only having 24-player mode in the pipeline for significant new content does not fundamentally impact what people can create.  These are my thoughts on CTGP's current state. I'm sure my experiences and expectations differ from the typical player, but hopefully there's something you find worth considering for CTGP's future.

column231: The quality of tracks and removals keeps getting higher in recent time which is great to see, but leaving in tracks like peaks and six king is extremely questionable. All in all however the overall quality IS getting higher, which bumps it up from a 3 to a 4 to me.

The above rating mainly reflects my feelings of the track list and not other aspects of CTGP that much. Currently I have little to nothing wrong with it, but I have more fun playing other CT packs such as Mario Kart Midnight, and have been playing those packs more than CTGP these past few months whenever I want to play custom tracks.  I'm pretty light when it comes to my opinions on tracks, and there's very few I'd say I dislike, not just tracks in CTGP, but when it comes to all the custom tracks released. I don't set my expectations high when playing a track for the first time, and having created several tracks myself, I know the process isn't very easy. Both of these help me find at least something of value in most tracks I play, and it makes it pretty difficult for me to say any negative comments about a custom track unless it is something more objective. (if it's impossible to complete part of the track for example) It's quite a bit of the reason why most of my votes were Keep or Indifferent, though most if not all the tracks I put Remove for, I don't dislike them very much. I guess they're more so my picks for tracks to be removed if I decided that.  I'm pretty indifferent to retros being in the pack as a whole. I enjoy playing some of them, but wouldn't be bummed if most of them were removed or something, as I tend to enjoy original designs a bit more. I think what I enjoy most from tracks is different from most people, I was thinking about this this morning, but a track like Dash Cannon Woods I enjoy more than various modern tracks that have more polished visuals. I think it has some charm to it, and I like the unique gameplay of it compared to other tracks. Though I'm not saying I dislike all "good looking tracks" because that'd be stupid and incorrect to say, I just care more about the gameplay and little glimpses of personality in a course. FFFF is a recent track that I think is good in visuals, gameplay, and charm, for example, and I'm excited to see that one in CTGP because it was my favorite from the CT Jam it comes from (PF from the same jam is quite cool too!)

column231: The current "meta" of original CT designs really hinders the growth of the community and prevents new players from getting into CTs and improving. There are a lot of actual well designed tracks that don't see the light of day in competitive because experienced players deem them to be "boring" because they don't have a funny TF input spindrift hop trick shroomless cut that saves 10 seconds. With that said, new players and existing RT mains who are looking to get into CTs competitively end up giving up and being unmotivated to learn a shitty jank abusing shortcuts in 100 tracks and this lack of influx of new players is what is killing competitive CTs (CT mains complain in Lounge about their being no activity and I think bad/outdated track design is the biggest culprit). Another minor issue is that most original designs are unnecessarily long, with about 20 or so tracks in the pack being over 3:30/4 minutes long (the longest RT is about 2:45ish long) and probably over 80% of them are longer than rBC. There is no need for tracks to be that long, it just demotivates players from TTing and practicing them.
